questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of fever with chills. MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of fever and chills, along with the MRCP showing multiple areas of intrahepatic beading is typical of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Option B: Caroli's disease is a rare congenital condition characterized by irregular dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts with a normal extrahepatic duct system. It is common in both sexes and mostly presents before the age of 30 years with abdominal pain, cholangitis, or end-stage liver disease. MRCP shows irregular, cystic dilation of the large proximal intrahepatic bile ducts with a normal common bile duct. 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an autoimmune condition characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intra and extra-hepatic biliary tree. It is a progressive condition that leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis. 

MRCP or ERCP will show demonstrate multifocal, diffuse dilatation and strictures of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary trees, this pattern is a beading or chain of lakes appearance. Pseudodiverticula of extrahepatic bile ducts are pathognomic of PSC. MRCP is useful in diagnosis and surveillance, while ERCP is reserved for the treatment of dominant strictures and to exclude malignancy. 

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis:

The common age group of primary sclerosing cholangitis is 30-45 years. Men are affected twice as commonly as women. Two-thirds of these cases are associated with ulcerative colitis. It is also associated with Riedel’s thyroiditis and retroperitoneal fibrosis. 10–20% of patients develop cholangiocarcinoma.

Clinical features of a patient with PSC include pruritis, fever, chills, right upper quadrant discomfort, jaundice, and weight loss. 

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable.

Liver biopsy excludes other causes of cholestatic liver disease and defines the stage of PSC. It shows onion skin concentric periductal fibrosis. With disease progression, periportal fibrosis occurs, progressing to bridging necrosis, and eventually biliary cirrhosis.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management involving resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.

Other options: 

Option C: Oriental cholangitis, also known as recurrent pyogenic cholangitis is characterized by recurrent attacks of cholangitis due to bile stasis and stone formation. Patients between 30-40 years and both sexes are equally affected. It is caused due to infections (liver flukes, E.coli, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Proteus). Patients present with Charcot's triad (intermittent fever, pain, and jaundice). MRCP shows intra or extrahepatic calculi, dilatation of ducts, and strictures. 

Option D: Biliary carcinoma  (cholangiocarcinoma) most commonly affects patients >60 years and presents with fever, abdominal pain, weight loss, and features of obstructive jaundice. MRCP shows irregular narrowing of the bile duct involved by the tumor, with asymmetric upstream dilatation of the intrahepatic ducts.

questions.text: According to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries, injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is:
questions.solution:
Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg’s type C injury.

Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

MRCP is the gold standard for complete morphological evaluation of the biliary tree. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. A HIDA scan can confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. 

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is widely used to anatomically define bile duct injuries.

Classification

  • Type A: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa
  • Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct.
  • Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct.
  • Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss.
  • Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury
    • E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus.
    • E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus
    • E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication.
    • E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts.
    • E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral and main bile ducts.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative day following a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation in a patient suspected of post-cholecystectomy biliary leaks.

Patients with post-cholecystectomy biliary leak usually present with fever, jaundice and abdominal pain.  USG is used for an initial evaluation in such cases and can show a collection in the sub-hepatic space. 

The most common bile leak following cholecystectomy is from the cystic duct. This can be treated by placing a biliary endoprosthesis (stent) in the common bile duct across the origin of the cystic duct.

MRCP shows fluid collections arising from bile leaks but cannot differentiate these from other causes of fluid collections.

ERCP is the best investigation as it has the advantage of being both diagnostic and therapeutic.  ERCP is useful post-cholecystectomy as there is a high likelihood of a retained stone and stone extraction and/or temporary stenting may be required. 

HIDA scan is the most sensitive investigation for biliary leakage.

CT scan can show focal fluid collections, ascites, biliary obstruction, hepatic atrophy, signs of secondary biliary cirrhosis and any vascular injury.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient came back to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the next best step?

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.solution: The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by drainage of fluid collections by pigtail insertion and administration of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics.

questions.text: Five days following a common bile duct injury resulting in a leak, a patient presents with fever and abdominal pain. What would be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the case of a common bile duct injury with a leak and a patient presenting with signs of localized peritonitis, the next step of management is an ultrasound-guided aspiration. This will be followed by ERCP and stenting.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most common cause of bile duct injury. Major biliary leakage is usually seen 2 to 10 days after cholecystectomy. Affected patients typically present with:

  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Bilious ascites
  • Mild jaundice
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevations in the serum levels of ALP and GGT.

Management of bile duct injury:

If the injury is identified during surgery:

  • Partial injury to the bile duct (<3mm) - repair the injury
  • Complete transection without loss of segment - anastomose over T-tube
  • Complete transection with loss of segment - close distal end and carry out Roux-en-Y hepaticoduodenostomy/jejunostomy

If the leak is suspected postoperatively:

Transabdominal ultrasonography is initially performed to assess the leak. 

  • If the patient presents within 48 hours - Re-explore and repair
  • If the patient presents after 48 hours - USG-guided aspiration or pigtail catheter insertion.

This is followed by ERCP and stenting.

questions.text: Where does biliary stricture most commonly occur after laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Biliary stricture after laparoscopic cholecystectomy usually occurs in the common hepatic duct, distal to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts.

After open cholecystectomy, biliary strictures are more common in the common bile duct.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about hemobilia?

choices.text: It is associated with Quincke's triad
Tumors are the most common cause of bleeding
Arterial angiography is the diagnostic procedure of choice

questions.solution:
The most common cause of hemobilia is iatrogenic trauma.

Hemobilia is defined as bleeding into the biliary tree from abnormal communication between a blood vessel and bile duct.

Causes of hemobilia include:

  • Traumatic or operative injury to the liver or bile ducts
  • Intraductal rupture of a hepatic abscess or aneurγsm of the hepatic artery
  • Biliary or hepatic tumor hemorrhage
  • Mechanical complications of choledocholithiasis or hepatobiliary parasitism
  • Diagnostic procedures, such as liver biopsy, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC), and transhepatic biliary drainage catheter placement
  • Vascular disorders

Patients often present with a classic triad (Quincke's triad/Sandblom triad) of:

  • Biliary pain
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Melena or occult blood in the stools

Investigation of choice: Arterial angiography (CT angiography) is the diagnostic procedure of choice.

Management: 

Minor hemobilia can be managed conservatively.

Major hemobilia: Transarterial embolization is indicated for major hemobilia requiring blood transfusion. Ligation of the bleeding vessel may also be required.

questions.text: How will you confirm the diagnosis in a patient suspected to have bilhemia?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation for the diagnosis of bilhemia.

Bilhemia is a condition in which bile flows into the bloodstream through the hepatic veins or portal vein branches. This flow occurs due to a high intrabiliary pressure, exceeding that of the venous system.

The cause can be the erosion of gallstones into the portal vein, or accidental/iatrogenic trauma. This condition can be fatal secondary to the embolization of large amounts of bile into the lungs. Usually, bile flow is low, and the fistulas close spontaneously.

Its clinical features include:

  • Rapidly progressive jaundice
  • Marked direct hyperbilirubinemia, without elevation of the hepatocellular enzyme levels.
  • Septicemia.

Diagnosis of bilhemia is best made by ERCP.

Treatment is directed at reducing the intrabiliary pressure through stent placement or sphincterotomy. Endovascular embolization can also be done.

questions.text:
Cholangiohepatitis is associated with which of the following parasites?
  1. Clonorchis sinensis
  2. Opisthorchis viverrini
  3. Schistosoma haematobium
  4. Ascaris lumbricoides
  5. Paragonimus westermani
questions.solution:
Cholangiohepatitis or recurrent pyogenic cholangitis is associated with biliary parasites such as:

  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Opisthorchis viverrini
  • Ascaris lumbricoides.

It is caused by bacterial contamination of the biliary tree. Some commonly implicated organisms are Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species, Bacteroides species, or Enterococcus faecalis.

Cholangiohepatitis is a pre-malignant condition and can result in cholangiocarcinoma.

Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis. 

Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke) causes a pulmonary syndrome characterized by cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of weight loss, clay coloured stools, and abdominal pain. CT scan and MRCP was suggestive of cholangiocarcinoma. What is the most common site at which this occurs?

choices.text: Distal third of the common bile duct
Middle third of the common bile duct
Confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts

questions.solution:
Cholangiocarcinomas are most common at the location where the right and left hepatic ducts meet i.e., the confluence of the hepatic ducts. 

Cholangiocellular carcinomas (CCCs) or cholangiocarcinomas are mucin-producing adenocarcinomas of the biliary duct system that may originate in the liver and extrahepatic bile ducts. Cholangiocarcinomas are encountered in three anatomic regions:

  • Intrahepatic
  • Hilar (65%) - also known as Klatskin tumours
  • Peripheral (30%)

The sclerosing variant of cholangiocarcinoma is the most common and most difficult to treat. The nodular variant is usually intrahepatic and presents as a mass lesion. The papillary variant is rare and is associated with favourable outcomes.

 

Portoenterostomy is done for hilar cholangiocarcioma and for peripheral cholangiocarcionoma, Whipple's surgery is done.

In Bismuth-Corlette classification they are classified according to their location:

The FDA approved Pemigatinib, FGFR2 inhibitor for patients with cholangiocarcinoma that is locally advanced or metastatic, and tumors with fusion or rearrangement of fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 (FGFR2) gene.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient presented with right upper quadrant pain. USG and CT scans showed no evidence of gallstones. MRCP shows fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct. Identify the false statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Jaundice will be the most consistent finding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRCP showing fusiform dilation of extrahepatic biliary tree point towards the diagnosis of a choledochal cyst (Type I). Choledochal cysts are more commonly seen in females. 

A choledochal cyst is a premalignant condition leading to the development of cholangiocarcinoma. 

The classic clinical triad of symptoms includes abdominal pain, jaundice (most consistent finding), and a mass in the abdomen.

Diagnosis of choledochal cyst can be made by:

  • USG (Initial investigation)
  • MRCP (Investigation of choice)
  • ERCP (Gold standard investigation)
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (Most sensitive)

Management includes effective drainage and removal of abnormal mucosa to reduce the risk of malignancy.

Type of choledochal cyst Surgical management
Type I Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II Diverticulectomy + common bile duct repair
Type III ERCP + sphincterotomy (Only cyst in which reconstruction is not required)
Type IVa and Type V Liver transplant
Type IVb Kasai procedure (portoenterostomy)

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: What is the most common type of choledochal cyst?
questions.solution:
Type I is the most common type of choledochal cyst (75%).

Choledochal cysts are congenital dilations of the intra- and/or extra-hepatic biliary system.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. In the Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop is anastomosed to the hepatic hilum.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.
